title: Wednesday, 12th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hiya -- welcome to Markets Live

PM11:02am

Suppose this fella deserves to be our pic of the day

PM11:03am

(Sorry bear with, tech snafu)

11:03 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

there!

PM11:03am

Alf Göransson, of course

11:03 am
PM11:03am

President of Securitas

PM11:03am

The giant security firm

PM11:04am

Had his identity stolen

11:04 am
PM11:04am

It was used for a loan application and then a bankruptcy application

PM11:04am

Which was granted in Stockholm

PM11:04am

Oops

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Securitas President and CEO Alf Göransson has been exposed to stolen identity and falsified bankruptcy application.

At the end of March 2017, Securitas President and CEO Alf Göransson was robbed on his personal identification, when a person made a loan application in Alf Göransson’s name.

On April 5, 2017, the incident was reported to the police by Alf Göransson. Alf Göransson has not received any information about if the loan was payed, the sum and the kind of loan application.

On July 10, 2017, Alf Göransson was declared bankrupt by the Stockholm District Court, without any contact before the decision.

PM11:05am

The decision by the Stockholm District Court is based on a falsified application, where Alf Göransson is requesting himself in bankruptcy. The incident has been reported to the police and the decision will be appealed to the Court of Appeal immediately today. The Bankruptcy Trustee appointed by Stockholm District Court has been informed and says he will support the appeal of the bankruptcy decision, which thereby is expected to be removed.

PM11:05am

Could happen to any of us, I guess

11:05 am
PM11:06am

I once got a visit from the cops, saying a guy at the centre of a money laundering case was claiming to be me.

PM11:06am

Never heard anything more about it.

undefined
11:06 am
PM11:06am

Anyway, that was a distraction really

PM11:06am

There's loads of trading statements

PM11:06am

And other stuff

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Bryce

PM11:07am

Have you noticed what's missing in this market?

PM11:07am

Dead cats

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Deadcat nowhere to be seen

PM11:07am

If you get hit hard on day one, you get hit hard again on day 2

PM11:07am

And maybe, in the case of Carillion, Day 3

11:07 am
PM11:08am

Punishment is ongoing

PM11:08am

Pearson is on Day 2, currently

BE11:08am

Yeah, okay, we can start with the casualties list.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

We don't have to!

BE11:09am

Well, it's as good a place as any, as both Carillion and Pearson do rather pull the rug from the idea that we deal with efficient markets.

BE11:10am

To recap, Carillion's merger with Balfour fell apart in ... 2014? was it? ... and everyone had a good look at their construction contract book and said, "hang on, these numbers look a bit aggressive."

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Then, a mere three years later and with 30% of the stock out on loan, Carillion says, "yes, well, about that ........"

BE11:11am

Meanwhile, on Pearson, the management say in January, "we're going to rebase the divi"

BE11:11am

Then they say yesterday's statement "the divi is strong and stable" or someshuch.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And it takes cross-questioning in the conference call for anyone to realise that the underlying message here is that Penguin earnings aren't in the divi coverage ratio any more.

PM11:12am

Well, suppose the new dividend yield is improving as the week progresses...

BE11:13am

The divi guidance was a surprise? I mean, management could have been clearer, I guess -- but if you're an analyst covering Pearson then a fair proportion of the job is translating management statements into English.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Anyway, by yesterday's close was the realisation that Pearson was now yielding 2 per cent, 3 per cent at best.

BE11:14am

And it appeared they've just executed a stealth 70% divi cut.

BE11:14am

At least, we thought that was the realisation.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Seems not, tho. Seems some people woke up this morning -- some people managing your pension! -- and thought, "oh, wait a minute ...."

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 621.03, down 33.97 (-5.19%), High: 650.00, Low: 617.50, Volume: 3.74m
PM11:15am

Scorchedfingers

11:16 am
BE11:16am

I mean, we copy-pasted all the relevant bits of the conference call yesterday! Why? Is? This? Divi? Stuff? A? Surprise?

BE11:16am

Let me get some sellside to hammer home the point.

BE11:16am

Panmure.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

We move from Hold to Sell, following clarification of the new dividend policy in the wake of a part-disposal of the PRH holding. The guidance suggests a dividend of around 15p for FY17E (compared to previous market expectations of 20-31p), rising to perhaps 18p at the most by FY19E. This implies a dividend yield range of 2.3%-2.7% and essentially takes away any yield support for the stock, in our view. Our first estimate for EPS, adjusted for the transaction, is around 44p in FY17E, rising only modestly thereafter driven by the net of cost cutting versus top line declines. Valuation at 15x EPS looks too high given a continuing challenging and opaque outlook for the business (ITV and DMGT offer less structural risk in our view, at 11x and 12x EPS respectively). We cut our Target Price for Pearson from 625p to 525p, based on 12x FY17E EPS.

BE11:18am

Implication for dividend estimates. Pearson has reiterated its current year guidance range of 48.5p-55.5p of EPS for FY17E – as ever based on constant scope, and FX rates as at the start of the year ($1.23). Pearson indicated on its call that this guidance included around a 15p contribution from the (47% of) PRH, and also that ‘comfortable’ dividend cover implies ‘a bit more than 2x’. Adjusting for the PRH contribution, a cover level of 2.5x, 6% buyback accretion, and current FX of $1.29 not $1.23, we estimate a FY17E dividend payment in the range of 14-16p. For FY19E, the same calculation suggests a dividend payment of around 14p (based on our below-consensus FY19E EPS estimate of 50p) or 18p (based on consensus EPS forecasts of 60p). The broad range implied here – call it 15-18p – is well below previous consensus expectations for the dividend (FY17E consensus 27p according to Thomson Reuters, with a range of 20p-31p).

PM11:18am

(fortyeight -- hehe -- the actual advice was "scarper")

11:18 am
BE11:18am

That divi consensus looks a bit stale, incidentally. I think we said 25p in the paper overnight.

BE11:19am

Our first cut at new EPS estimates, adjusted for the disposal, buyback, and current FX, suggests EPS of around 44p in FY17E. This rises modestly thereafter out to FY20E, reflecting the balance between the £300m of “round three” cost savings indicated in May, versus ongoing top line pressures, and dilution from potential further disposals (US K12 courseware, WSE, GEDU, the final 25% of PRH). Based on the current share price this suggests a valuation of around 15x FY17E EPS, which looks expensive to us given the depth of the structural, regulatory, and cyclical challenges the group continues to face in its core education markets. We would argue that, within the sector, both ITV and DMGT offer lower structural risk at more attractive valuations (11x and 12x current EPS respectively). Moreover, an accompanying dividend payout level for Pearson in the region of 15-18p means the shares no longer have any real yield support in our view (implied yield of 2.3-2.7%). We move our Target Price down from 625p to 525p, at which level the shares would offer a less demanding valuation of around 12x near term EPS.

PM11:19am

(Marketman -- we had to take the transcript down cos of a problem. Should be up again later today.)

11:20 am
PM11:20am

You've vented your spleen ther eBryce

BE11:20am

I'm a tad irritable this morning.

undefined
11:20 am
BE11:20am

As for Carillion ...........

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 70.50, down 7.4 (-9.50%), High: 80.60, Low: 68.00, Volume: 19.97m
PM11:20am

ScorchedfingersScorchedfingersScorchedfingers

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Proper volume behind it too. Folk were long this thing, in spite of overwhelming evidence that it was a value trap.

BE11:22am

RBC's the latest out of the traps to say, "expect a rights issue, or worse."

BE11:22am

New forecasts: In reality, these are largely irrelevant given the high degree of uncertainty on the future strategic direction of the group and ongoing risks. However, these do provide a base to drive our rights issue analysis. At the headline level, we cut FY17E PBT by 20% to £144.7m and EPS by a similar level to 27.5p. For FY18E, we have cut PBT by 16% to £147.2m and EPS by 17% to 27.9p. We have not assumed any resumption in the payment of a dividend over our forecast horizon. Adjusted spot net debt increases by c£290m to £487.8m in FY18E.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

In our view, a rights issue is the most obvious course of action. We believe that £600m could be required and assuming a 40% discount to the current share price, would imply an EPS base of 9.2p (67% dilution to new forecasts). This would take average net debt to EBITDA down to 1.2x, a more sensible level of near-term leverage. We would also not rule out the disposal of its Construction operations - given these are the main source of risk and working capital volatility in the group. A focused Support Services business could be more palatable from a turnaround perspective and future valuation.

BE11:23am

A reminder that Carillion expect to announce the plan in September.

BE11:24am

And the plan is nearly certain to involve new equity -- possibly in rights issue form or, if things get real hairy, in exchange for debt. So, plenty of time for a death spiral to develop.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Omg smile

BE11:25am

It is difficult to take a firm stance on valuation, given the high degree of probability in a change to its capital structure. However, on current forecasts, our sum-of-the-parts based valuation indicates a fair value of 100p. If we were to consider c10p as a sensible earnings base post a rights issue, then a 10-12x multiple on this would not be out of kilter with what we have seen at other special situations in the sector.

PM11:25am

People wondering about if/when the shorts cover

11:25 am
PM11:25am

It's obvious to my mind: they close in the rescue rights

BE11:26am

It's a fair question. Dunno. Remember this isn't some kind of short-term trade. Short's been 20% plus since early 2015.

BE11:26am

Mentioned the UBS note in the paper overnight, which has a downside target of nil.

11:26 am
PM11:27am

ouch

BE11:27am

The idea here is that the core services business starts to deteriorate and Carillion busts through its debt facilities mid quarter.

BE11:27am

Which isn't implausible.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

In a downside scenario, margins come under pressure in all divisions. Support services would see no sales growth and margins compress to 5.0% and the two construction segments settle at margins of around 1.5-%2%. We factor in additional cash flow pressures from working capital of a further £100m. While we do not believe there are short-term liquidity constraints, a situation where cash flow deteriorates intra-quarter and goes above the £1.5bn total facility size, we would see a risk on solvency. Given the high level of leverage the equity is highly sensitive to assumptions made at the operational level as well as multiples applied. While our derived equity value would be negative, we apply 0p as the maximum amount of downside though recognise some option value may remain for current shareholders making the valuation downside a relatively low probability event.

BE11:28am

Their base case is 78p, which looked harsh yesterday but not so much today.

undefined
11:29 am
PM11:29am

Amec Foster

Amec Foster Wheeler PLC (AMFW:LSE): Last: 426.10, down 28.9 (-6.35%), High: 436.80, Low: 401.30, Volume: 4.87m
PM11:29am

When you think about it -- this was obvious as well

11:29 am
PM11:29am

We knew of the SFOs interest

PM11:30am

And since the SFO got threatened with closure they were/are going to pursue everything they can

PM11:30am

It was the same with the FSA when they got threatened with the chop

11:30 am
PM11:30am

They went out and started arresting bid gossips

PM11:31am

SFO after Barclays of course as well -- same forces at work, i suspect

BE11:31am

Yep -- it's all clangingly, screamingly, klaxon-soundingly obvious.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Partly because Wood Group CFO David Kemp already told the market.

BE11:32am

See his comments to Bloomberg in mid June about Amec "disclos[ing] information" to US authorities.

BE11:32am

"To be absolutely clear, would we prefer not to have a Unaoil challenge? Absolutely, [...] You balance what we think is a really strong strategic rationale, really strong financial benefit, and there’s some challenges."

11:32 am
BE11:32am

That kind of thing.

BE11:33am

And, of course, it was in the prospectus.

BE11:33am

Issued May 24, so everyone should've had time to read that.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

However, uncertainty is uncertainty. Let's grab some sellside to tell us that investors don't like uncertainty.

BE11:34am

Morgan Stanley.

BE11:34am

We see confirmation of the investigation as increasing the uncertainty around the AMEC investment case and by extension that for the new combined Wood Group post deal close, guided for early 4Q17. The analysis in our note; Petrofac: Deep Dive into past SFO Cases Suggests Prolonged Uncertainty, found that on average SFO investigations take 2-3 years to resolve. This suggests at the very least an ongoing overhang from this issue that will most likely be reflected in a valuation discount.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Key differences to Petrofac: We however, do see key differences to the Petrofac case and therefore do not expect a similar ~50% fall in stock price. We believe the better comparisons are the stock reactions of ABB (inline with market) and KBR (underperformed ~10%) relating to SFO investigations.

BE11:35am

1. The topic isn't new, but confirmation of a flagged risk whereby the market has already somewhat priced in the outcome after the May 24th prospectus
2. SFO announcement relates to suspected bribery and corruption, but not money laundering as was the allegation for Petrofac. We consider the Money Laundering aspect a key differentiator and area of concern in the latter case that is not mentioned for AMEC, KBR or ABB.
3. The combined Wood Group-AMEC company does not have balance sheet issues in terms of liquidity or refinancing, which have been a key investor debate at Petrofac
4. Historical Foster Wheeler has less exposure to onshore MENA Lump-sum EPC contracts than Petrofac where it is the majority of the business. We see this as relevant for $ exposure to Unaoil linked contracts (for possible/potential future fines) and franchise risk of securing future contracts.
5. Likewise exposure to the Middle East and CIS, where Unaoil largely operates, is less for AMEC and historical Foster Wheeler than Petrofac. We estimate that AMEC Foster Wheeler combined is less than 10% exposed to MENA + CIS.
6. Both Wood Group and AMEC have less 'key man' risk than Petrofac where the CEO is founder and owns 18% of the company.

PM11:36am

(Upaswellasdown -- will save your blushes...)

11:35 am
BE11:36am

So, no panic.

BE11:36am

We do not expect any impact on the acquisition by Wood Group. Wood Group management were aware of the SFO dialogue and role of DoJ into Foster Wheeler's past business, now owned by AMEC, before the bid and both sets of shareholders have now approved the deal. We believe this leaves little recourse for changing tack or the terms of deal. We continue to prefer playing the deal through the Wood Group side and the SFO announcement only reinforces this view.

BE11:37am

Jefferies is less sure.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Not yet in the share price of either company, in our view. WG, as a proxy for the proforma merged WG-AMFW company, is trading slightly above its five-year average EV/EBITDA FY+1 of 7.7x; the same is true for adjusted PE FY+1 at 12.9x. While not a comparable situation (every SFO investigation is specific to the company and circumstances involved), the sell-off in Petrofac to multiples roughly half this level (4x FY+1 EV/EBITDA & 6.5x FY+1) following its SFO situation suggests some derating of valuation is likely for both WG and AMFW, and this is ahead of interim results for both companies where we expect weak results and cautious outlook to possibly cause further consensus downgrades. AMFW 1H17 results 10 August, WG 1H17 results 22 August.

BE11:37am

Our view on the deal (and AMFW as a stand-alone ahead of that deal) is based on our analysis that a) cashflow demands of a progressive dividend take money away that in the past was used for M&A (by both companies)...this affects b) revenue projections in the absence of bolt-on M&A are likely too optimistic, in our view, coupled with oil & gas industry activity slowdown and price deflation/efficiency gains even when activity returns (this is before we get to asset sales impact). Finally, c) analysis shows that cost synergy savings are largely absorbed at the trading profit or EBITA level. Combining these factors into d) a valuation largely in line with five-year average mulitples means the companies are open to underperform, particularly if operations are weaker than expected. e) All these factors are independent of SFO impacts and are subject to the WG-AMFW deal going through as expected, and we note AMFW's announcement states that "the SFO's investigation is not expected to have an impact on the completion of the merger of Amec Foster Wheeler and John Wood Group, which is expected to take place in the fourth quarter of this year."

Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 2,055, down 143 (-6.51%), High: 2,184, Low: 2,049, Volume: 567.87k
BE11:43am

Really, really bad time for a licence sales miss.

PM11:43am

(Oh, on Snap, people might want to visit the usual place Wink smile )

11:43 am

BE11:44am

BE11:45am

Is this the Credit Suisse "faster extinction of legacy tech" scenario playing out? Maybe.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

And it's not the ideal backdrop for a gigantic takeover of a ragbag of legacy assets that have seen sales crumble, and have some fairly fundamental questions regarding valuation overhanging them anyway.

PM11:47am

hmm

BE11:47am

Sellside quite positive, FWIW. Here's Canaccord.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Results for the year to April 2017 were broadly in line with expectations. We summarise the headline results below versus Bloomberg and Reuters consensus and our own CG forecasts. Revenues fell 0.9% on an underlying basis versus guidance at start of the year of flat to down 2%. Underlying adjusted EBITDA was around 2% below consensus with a margin of 46.4% versus our own 47%. Adjusted diluted EPS was up 20% to 176c and just above consensus. There was a small upside surprise on cash where conversion of EBITDA came in at 102% leaving net debt at $1411m versus consensus of $1485m.

BE11:48am

We consider these results to be in line with expectations. We would put the very small miss on margins down to decisions made with HPE joining the group on 1 Sept being slightly different to those that might have been taken had this not been the case. Chairman Kevin Loosemore re-iterated the Group's target of delivering 15% to 20% shareholder returns per annum and this looks to be very much on track.

BE11:48am

We believe that the recent fall in the shares may reflect investor concerns around the flow-back of stock from US funds holding HPE, but which may be unable to hold Micro Focus. We expect this technical situation to unwind in due course, such that an entry point of around 2,200p will prove attractive. This is only some 10% above the price at which the deal was announced and we forecast accretion, by year two post closure, of around 70%. It also offers good upside to our target price based on a year two EV/ EBITDA of 10x versus a long term average for Micro Focus of around 11x. We retain our BUY recommendation and remain strong supporters of this highly accretive and value creating deal.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

And Barclays.

BE11:49am

[On May 9] Micro Focus announced that HPE Software revenue was down c. 10% y/y, driven by licence and services decline with support and SaaS broadly flat. In the event, they were down 9%, but it was the ongoing improvement in profitability that offered some relief with a 10%pt improvement in the margin y/y on an underlying basis. Micro Focus will be in full control of the business from 1 September and we expect it to introduce new quota carrying sales comp plans. The rebuild of the pipeline and the sales execution are likely to take two to three quarters to fix, in our view, and it is prudent to anticipate further weak licences, although we note that it is approaching an easy comp (3Q16: -17%). Nonetheless, the full approval for the deal is the overriding point.

BE11:50am

Micro Focus’s reverse merger with HPE Software is an unprecedented transaction and was unlikely to avoid any issues from beginning to end. The weaker Q2 from HPE Software was disappointing, but largely outside of Micro Focus’s control and; with an easier Q3 comp and the merger completing in Q4, performance should improve from here. The bigger picture is that shareholder and regulatory approvals have been received, the debt financing is in place and the deal is on track for a scheduled close. Today’s results from Micro Focus are clearly a touch softer than the first half, but are nonetheless in line with guidance and some modest disruption as a consequence of the impending merger is to be expected. At 11x our FY20E EPS the investment case is intact and we reiterate Overweight.

BE12:02pm

BE12:02pm

........... nothing to add to what was written on Monday, and we said at the time that it wasn't a story that was likely to require any kind of formal response.

BE12:03pm

And to be clear we've had no response, formal or informal, to the idea that Sir Peter isn't against the idea of selling eSure.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

BE12:04pm

BE12:04pm

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

Strong Motor segment more than offsets weak Home: Continued motor premium inflation has supported strong UK motor topline growth over the first quarter of the year, which we expect to continue over the course of the year. We forecast c9% CAGR in industry rates rises over 2017-19e, which remains comfortably ahead of our expectations of mid-single digit claims inflation. Home trends remain weak given soft premium rises from intense competition, with heightened claims inflation a key challenge. We forecast 1% CAGR in home industry rates rises over 2017-19e. We continue to be positive on the UK non-life subsector as offering a good combination of capital returns and topline growth.

BE12:05pm

Upgrade Direct Line to Outperform, downgrade Esure to Neutral: We view Direct Line's current greater than 20% discount compared to peers as excessive, particularly given solid 6-7% total FCF and dividend yield prospects, which are at the top-end of the subsector. Direct Line also looks the cheapest from a HOLT® (Credit Suisse valuation tool) perspective. Following strong share price performance (up c50% YTD), we downgrade Esure to Neutral as we view double digit top-line and earnings momentum as now reflected at current share prices.

BE12:05pm

We remain positive on RSA and Hastings. We see appeal in RSA's
dividend and earnings recovery given ongoing self-help and Hastings' capital-light and nimble cost model which should support profitable growth. Admiral is our least preferred name as we view valuation as full. We remain Neutral on Saga as we see limited upside from current share prices.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Nothing in there whatsoever on sector consolidation.

undefined

Premier Oil PLC (PMO:LSE): Last: 58.96, up 12.71 (+27.49%), High: 64.00, Low: 57.00, Volume: 31.57m

12:07 pm
PM12:07pm

https://www.invest...1707120700048116K/

PM12:07pm

Premier, together with its joint venture partners Talos Energy (Operator) and Sierra Oil & Gas, is pleased to announce that the Zama-1 exploration well in Block 7, offshore Mexico, has made a world class oil discovery. The Zama-1 well is the first offshore exploration well drilled by the private sector in Mexico's history. Premier holds a 25 per cent interest in the block.

12:11 pm
BE12:12pm

PMO (25% working interest) stated that the well has encountered up to 200m of net pay (335m gross oil bearing interval), with no oil-water contact and initial gross original oil in place estimate of greater than 1bn bbl, based on preliminary analysis. Note that one of the partners in the project, Riverstone Energy (40%), are quoting a range of 1.4-2bn bbl. Hydrocarbon samples taken from the well indicate light oil with API of 28-30.

BE12:12pm

See? 2bn, potentially.

BE12:12pm

The partners still have 100-150m of further drilling to reach the
initial target at which point we may get a further update on the discovery. The partners will then target a deeper, higher-risk prospect, Zama deep, for which we do not carry any value at this stage. Once the drilling is complete, the partners will be able to assess full results and plan follow-on appraisal drilling possibly in 2018.

12:12 pm

Our TP of 60p and Underperform rating remain unchanged.

BE12:13pm

And Barclays.

BE12:13pm

Premier’s 25% stake in the Zama-1 well can be transformational for the indebted oil producer/developer and provides a welcome change of pace for an investment case dominated by debt refinancing and oil price sensitivity. While there is clearly more work to be done to confirm the scale of Zama and the path towards development, we expect investors to begin assigning value for the asset. We estimate the initial result could add ~10p/share on a risked basis, all else being equal.

12:13 pm
BE12:13pm

The first offshore exploration well drilled by the private sector in Mexico has discovered an estimated 1 billion barrels of oil in place within a 200m net oil bearing reservoir. Initial sampling indicates a light oil and some associated gas. The well is to be deepened to test further the higher-risk Zama deep prospect, and we would expect appraisal activity to begin in 2018. The discovery could extend beyond the block into acreage 100% held by PEMEX but currently scheduled for relinquishment.

Premier holds a 25% working interest in Block 7. Our pre-drill modeling of Zama assumed a 150mmbbl prospect with an unrisked PV/bbl of $2.10/bbl. Assuming a ~40% recovery factor on the greater than 1bnbbl oil in place estimate, we provisionally calculate the discovery could be worth ~30p/share on a fully unrisked basis; transformational when set against our current 63p/share Tangible NAV that includes no value for the Mexican acreage. We would note that Premier’s partners have indicated a higher oil in place estimate of 1.5-2 billion barrels.
